column1: 2012M&PS...47..120T|2012|Resolution of impact-related microstructures in lunar zircon: A shock-deformation mechanism map|Timms
column14: Robert|Meteoritics and Planetary Science|47|1|120|The microstructures of lunar zircon grains from breccia samples 72215
column17: and 76295 collected during the Apollo 17 mission have been characterized via optical microscopy
column19: and electron backscatter diffraction mapping. These zircon grains preserve deformation microstructures that show a wide range in style and complexity. Planar deformation features (PDFs) are documented in lunar zircon for the first time
column23: typically with 0.1-25 μm spacing. The widest PDFs associated with {112} contain microtwin lamellae with 65°/<110> misorientation relationships. Deformation bands parallel to {100} planes and irregular low-angle (<10°) boundaries most commonly have <001> misorientation axes. This geometry is consistent with a dislocation glide system with <100>{010} during dislocation creep. Nonplanar fractures
column26: and localized annealing textures along fractures are also observed. No occurrences of reidite were detected. Shock-deformation microstructures in zircon are explained in terms of elastic anisotropy of zircon. PDFs form along a limited number of specific {hkl} planes that are perpendicular to directions of high Young's modulus
column27: suggesting that PDFs are likely to be planes of longitudinal lattice damage. Twinned {112} PDFs also contain directions of high shear modulus. A conceptual model is proposed for the development of different deformation microstructures during an impact event. This “shock-deformation mechanism map” is used to explain the relative timing
column29: and complexity relationships between impact-related deformation microstructures in zircon.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1945-5100.2011.01316.x

column1: 2008GeCoA..72.3022P|2008|Osmium isotope and highly siderophile element systematics of lunar impact melt breccias: Implications for the late accretion history of the Moon and Earth|Puchtel
column8: David A.|Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|72|12|3022|To characterize the compositions of materials accreted to the Earth-Moon system between about 4.5 and 3.8 Ga
column9: we have determined Os isotopic compositions and some highly siderophile element (HSE: Re
column14: and Pd) abundances in 48 subsamples of six lunar breccias. These are: Apollo 17 poikilitic melt breccias 72395 and 76215; Apollo 17 aphanitic melt breccias 73215 and 73255; Apollo 14 polymict breccia 14321; and lunar meteorite NWA482
column15: a crystallized impact melt. Plots of Ir versus other HSE define excellent linear correlations
column16: indicating that all data sets likely represent dominantly two-component mixtures of a low-HSE target
column19: presumably exogenous component. Linear regressions of these trends yield intercepts that are statistically indistinguishable from zero for all HSE
column20: except for Ru and Pd in two samples. The slopes of the linear regressions are insensitive to target rock contributions of Ru and Pd of the magnitude observed; thus
column21: the trendline slopes approximate the elemental ratios present in the impactor components contributed to these rocks. The <SUP>187</SUP>Os/<SUP>188</SUP>Os and regression-derived elemental ratios for the Apollo 17 aphanitic melt breccias and the lunar meteorite indicate that the impactor components in these samples have close affinities to chondritic meteorites. The HSE in the Apollo 17 aphanitic melt breccias
column23: might partially or entirely reflect the HSE characteristics of HSE-rich granulitic breccia clasts that were incorporated in the impact melt at the time of its creation. In this case
column24: the HSE characteristics of these rocks may reflect those of an impactor that predated the impact event that led to the creation of the melt breccias. The impactor components in the Apollo 17 poikilitic melt breccias and in the Apollo 14 breccia have higher <SUP>187</SUP>Os/<SUP>188</SUP>Os
column26: and Ru/Ir and lower Os/Ir than most chondrites. These compositions suggest that the impactors they represent were chemically distinct from known chondrite types
column27: and possibly represent a type of primitive material not currently delivered to Earth as meteorites.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.gca.2008.04.006

column16: and for lunar meteorite NWA 482. The data indicate that some of the lunar rocks diverge from the known chondrite groups.|

column1: 2006LPI....37.1428P|2006|Further Study of 187Os/188Os and Highly Siderophile Element Systematics of Apollo 14 and 17 Impact Melt Rocks|Puchtel
column6: O. B.|37th Annual Lunar and Planetary Science Conference|37||1428|New 187Os/188Os and HSE data for lunar impact melt rocks indicate that 73215 and 73255 aphanites plot in the middle of the chondrite range

column1: 2001M&PS...36.1257M|2001|Siderophile elements in Earth's upper mantle and lunar breccias: Data synthesis suggests manifestations of the same late influx|Morgan
column8: M. F.|Meteoritics and Planetary Science|36|9|1257|The platinum group elements (PGE; Ru
column14: Re and Au comprise the highly siderophile elements (HSE). We re-examine selected isotopic and abundance data sets for HSE in upper mantle peridotites to resolve a longstanding dichotomy. Re-Os and Pt-Os isotope systematics
column15: and approximately chondritic proportions of PGE in these rocks suggest the presence in undepleted mantle of a chondrite-like component
column16: which is parsimoniously explained by late influx of large planetisimals after formation of the Earth's core and the Moon. But some suites of xenolithic and orogenic spinel lherzolites
column18: have a CI-normalized PGE pattern with enhanced Pd that is sometimes termed "non-chondritic". We find that this observation is consistent with other evidence of a late influx of material more closely resembling enstatite
column20: chondrites. Regional variations in HSE patterns may be a consequence of a late influx of very large objects of variable composition. Studies of many ancient (>3.8 Ga) lunar breccias show regional variations in Au/Ir and suggest that "graininess" existed during the early bombardment of the Earth and Moon. Reliable Pd values are available only for Apollo 17 breccias 73215 and 73255
column21: however. Differences in HSE patterns between the aphanitic and anorthositic lithologies in these breccias show fractionation between a refractory group (Re
column22: Os and Ir) and a normal (Pd
column24: and Au) group and may reflect the compositions of the impacting bodies. Similar fractionation is apparent between the EH and EL chondrites
column25: whose PGE patterns resemble those of the aphanitic and anorthositic lithologies
column26: respectively. The striking resemblance of HSE and chalcogen (S
column27: Se) patterns in the Apollo aphanites and high Pd terrestrial peridotites suggest that the "non-chondritic" abundance ratios in the latter may be reflected in the composition of planetisimals striking the Moon in the first 700 Ma of Earth-Moon history. Most notably
column28: high Pd may be part of a general enhancement of HSE more volatile than Fe suggesting that the Au abundance in at least parts of the upper mantle may be 1.5 to 2 times higher than previously estimated. The early lunar influx may be estimated from observed basin-sized craters. Comparison of relative influx to Earth and Moon suggests that the enrichment of HSE is limited to the upper mantle above 670 km. To infer enrichment of the whole mantle would require several large lunar impacts not yet identified.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1945-5100.2001.tb01959.x

column1: 1987JGR....92E.432R|1987|Chemical composition and origin of Apollo 15 impact melts|Ryder
column4: Paul|Journal of Geophysical Research|92|B4|E432|To better understand the Apennine Front
column5: we have analyzed 14 Apollo 15 impact melt rocks
column9: for major (fused bead microprobe) and trace element (INAA) abundances. The melt rocks show a remarkable diversity of chemical composition
column10: although all but one have typical KREEP incompatible-element patterns. They appear to form five chemical groups
column11: all but the most KREEP-rich of which may represent single impacts. Three groups are of low-K Fra Mauro composition; none correspond to very high alumina (VHA) compositions. The compositions are unlike nearly all other impact melts and regoliths from highland sites
column12: indicating a distinct provenance for the Apollo 15 samples. Serenitatis basin impact melt compositions (Apollo 17 poikilitic boulders) are not duplicated
column13: although one Apollo 17 aphanitic melt sample (73215) is similar to one of the Apollo 15 groups. The Apollo 15 group consisting only of 15445 and 15455 remains the best candidate for Imbrium basin impact melt
column14: while the most KREEP-rich group probably consists of melts produced in varied post-Imbrium impacts into the Apennine Bench Formation (Apollo 15 KREEP basalt flows). The most populated group was previously unrecognized and could be either pre- or post-Imbrium basin; it is possible that it
column16: represents Imbrium melt. One unique sample has a non-KREEP incompatible element pattern with low abundances and a positive Eu anomaly. Its target was rather primitive and would not appear to be of regional extent or present in the area in post-Imbrium times; it is either a pre-Imbrian melt or exotic. The Apennine Front does not consist of a monolithic LKFM composition but shows a much wider diversity of compositions than was previously recognized.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/JB092iB04p0E432

column10: although all but one have typical KREEP incompatible-element patterns. They appear to form five chemical groups
column11: all but the most KREEP-rich of which may represent single impacts. Three groups are of low-K Fra Mauro composition; none correspond to very high alumina (VHA) compositions. The compositions are unlike nearly all other impact melts and regoliths from highland sites
column12: indicating a distinct provenance for the Apollo 15 samples. Serenitatis basin impact melt compositions (Apollo 17 poikilitic boulders) are not duplicated
column13: although one Apollo 17 aphanitic melt sample (73215) is similar to one of the Apollo groups. The Apollo 15 group consisting only of 15445 and 14455 remains the best candidate for Imbrium basin impact melt
column14: while the most KREEP-rich group probably consists of melts produced in varied post-Imbrium impacts into the Apennine Bench Formation (Apollo 15 KREEP basalt flows). The most populated group was previously unrecognized and could be either pre- or post-Imbrium basin; it is possible that it

Its target was rather primitive and would not appear to be of regional extent or present in the area in post-Imbrium times; it is either a pre-Imbrian melt or exotic. The Apennine Front does not consist of a monolithic LKFM composition but shows a much wider diversity of compositions than was previously recognized.|

column1: 1979LPSC...10..803B|1979|Remnants from the ancient lunar crust: clasts from consortium breccia 73255.|Blanchard
column4: J. R.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||803|The paper examines analyses of clasts from consortium breccia 73255. It was shown that the basalts are high-alumina
column6: unfractionated abundances; the felsite is similar in major element composition and relative REE abundances to the felsites from 73215 and 12013; and the ANT materials are similar to the ANT clasts in other Apollo 17 breccias. Model calculations show that the pyroxene anorhosite has equilibrated with a very evolved liquid
column7: and it is indicated that there was once a liquid with an evolved REE composition which was the parent of the pyroxene anorthosite.|

column8: T.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||745|The results of an (Ar-40)-(Ar-39) study on four aphanitic samples and four lithic clasts from consortium breccia 73255 are reported. Thirteen samples from this exceptional breccia have now been dated. The methodological implications of the various types of age spectra are discussed in some detail. The results of this study and of previous studies of breccia 73215 indicate that the date of the South Serenitatis basin-forming event was 3.87 + or - 0.03 AE. This age is confirmed by recent dating of a felsite clast of 73255 with a plateau age of 3.89 + or - 0.03 AE. Some lithic clasts incorporated in the breccia are as old as 4.20 AE. The (Ar-38)C exposure age of 73255 is 91 + or - 3 my.|

column1: 1979LPSC...10..789M|1979|Breccias 73215 and 73255: siderophile and volatile trace elements.|Morgan
column4: R. K.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||789|Fifteen siderophile and volatile trace elements (Os
column18: Tl) and U were determined by radiochemical neutron activation analysis in a spheroidal aphanitic clast and a clast of coarse-grained anorthositic gabbro from breccia 73215 and in three types of aphanite and two clasts of fine-grained anorthositic gabbro from breccia 73255. In common with most Apollo 17 fragment-laden melt rocks
column19: the aphanites from 73215 and 73255 predominantly contain a Group 2 meteoritic component
column20: which is apparently derived from the Serenitatis impact. All aphanitic lithologies contain the same meteoritic component
column21: and are probably cogenetic. The clasts of fine-grained anorthositic gabbro contain substantial amounts (2% to 6% Cl equivalent based on Au) of a pre-Serenitatis Group 3 component. The clast of coarse-grained anorthositic gabbro is low in siderophile elements (0.4% Cl equivalent)
column22: and the meteoritic component (Group 5) is not well-defined. A strong correlation exists between Ir and Au in both the aphanites and the anorthositic gabbro clasts
column23: which argues against the breccias 73215 and 73255 being open systems for Au|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.2459J|1977|Petrology of four clasts from consortium breccia 73215.|James
column4: J. G.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2459|One felsite ('granite') and three ANT-suite anorthositic gabbro clasts extracted from breccia 73215 are described. The felsite clast has two components - fragments of crystalline felsite and veins and patches of felsic glass. The crystalline felsite
column5: which consists largely of a vermicular intergrowth of quartz and Ba-K-feldspar
column6: crystallized from a highly differentiated melt between 3.90 and 4.05 b.y. The felsic glass component consists of crystallized brown and colorless glasses and uncrystallized colorless glass which are all K and Si rich. The relation of glass features to past heating and the breccia-forming event is considered. In the three anorthositic gabbros
column7: which have similar mineralogies and gradational textures
column9: and olivine and orthopyroxene are the major mafic minerals. The petrologic data suggest that the gabbros formed as heated
column11: and/or recrystallized polymict breccias. It is possible that the approximately 4.25 b.y. age obtained for the three rocks is the date of the melting/recrystallization event.|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.2567J|1977|One rock and many ages - further K-Ar data on consortium breccia 73215.|Jessberger
column6: T.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2567|The Ar-40-Ar-39 dating of six subsamples of consortium breccia 73215 is reported
column7: and the ages for a total of 17 subsamples are found to range from 3.92 to 4.28 eons. The diversity demonstrates the limited resetting power of basin-forming events. Determination of the age of felsite
column8: an exceptional rock type found as a clast within the breccia
column9: indicates that the date of the breccia-forming event is 3.92 + or - 0.04 eons. If 73215 is consolidated Serenitatis ejecta
column10: then all circular basins must have formed between 3.78 and 3.92 eons; ages determined on most Apollo 17 highland rocks predate this period due to incomplete resetting.|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.2551M|1977|Laser probe <SUP>39</SUP>Ar-<SUP>40</SUP>Ar dating of materials from consortium breccia 73215.|Müller
column8: O. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2551|The unique capacity of the laser-probe (Ar-39)-(Ar-40) method to determine ages of constituents in a rock sample which are only of the order of 100 microns apart has been applied to measure ages of the different constituents of consortium breccia 73215. Evidence is given that the age of the melt-derived ground mass
column11: the best estimate for the age of the breccia-forming event
column13: comes from the study of two clasts only a few hundred micrometers in size. The interpretation of this age as the age of the breccia-forming event is also supported by the studies of other consortium members and suggests a reinterpretation of the ages of most of the other Apollo 17 highland breccias.|

column1: 1977LPSC....8.2525C|1977|Rb-Sr systematics ion clasts and aphanites from consortium breccia 73215.|Compston
column6: C. M.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2525|The presence of Rb-Sr mixing lines in samples of aphanitic matrix and aphanitic clasts from the light-gray breccias 73215 and Boulder 1 is considered with respect to age determination. Minimum and maximum age estimates for primary crystallization are reported. The nature of the unidentified component that causes some aphanites to show apparent ages of 4.6 eons is considered
column7: and the anomalous age is attributed to volatile loss of Rb at approximately 3.9 eons
column8: the date of crystallization. Clasts of anorthositic gabbro are found to have a Rb-Sr age of approximately 4.25 eons from inprecise internal isochrons
column9: while the model ages are 4.35 eons. It is suggested that if the clasts remained chemically closed during breccia formation
column10: the model ages are older limits to their primary igneous or metamorphic ages.|

column1: 1976LPSC....7.2145J|1976|Petrology of aphanitic lithologies in consortium breccia 73215.|James
column2: O. B.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2145|The paper describes the aphanitic rock that makes up the bulk of 73215

T.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2201|Light-gray consortium breccia 73215 is exceptional in that it was formed in a one stage event (presumably the excavation of Serenitatis Basin)
column8: and was not subsequently reheated. Ar-Ar ages of eleven clast and matrix samples yield plateau ages between 4.04 and 4.28 b.y. This is direct evidence against purely 'basin-dominated' chronologies. Matrix dominated by melts produced in the excavation event yields a basin age of about 4.05 b.y. The clasts were not completely reset upon excavation. Their ages probably reflect the age diversity of the impacted source regions in which the oldest clasts consolidated at or before about 4.25 b.y. ago.|

column1: 1975LPSC....6..707W|1975|Origin of the Station 7 boulder: a note.|Winzer
column10: J. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||707|The origin of the matrix types from the Apollo 17 Station 7 boulder is considered along with the origin of boulder material from Station 2
column12: and 73215. It is pointed out that the formation of the matrix rocks in this boulder and in the other Apollo 17 boulders in a single impact event is consistent with the isotopic evidence
column16: and textures. It had been suggested by Winzer et al. (1974)
column17: based on calculations from crystal-liquid partition coefficients for LIL trace elements
column18: that target rocks corresponding in trace-element composition to the matrix types could have been produced by partial fusion of rocks similar to 77215. Using the same type of calculation
column19: liquids quite similar in trace-element composition to the Station 7 boulder matrix types can be produced.|

column1: 1975LPSC....6..547J|1975|Consortium studies of matrix of light gray breccia 73215.|James
column38: L. R.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||547|A description is presented of the preliminary results of interdisciplinary studies of matrix samples. The significance of the 73215 studies is considered and the relationship of 73215 to other Apollo 17 highland breccias is discussed. According to a tentative hypothesis 73215 is an aggregate of fragments plus melt generated in a very large impact
column39: possibly the Serenitatis basin-forming event. If this is correct
column40: studies of this sample will make it possible to date the Serenitatis event and will provide an insight into the breccia-forming processes associated with such events. Studies of the clasts in the breccia will provide an opportunity to formulate a partial characterization of the preimpact source terrain. An investigation of the deep lunar crust might perhaps also be possible.|
